item.title: Modular Monolithic
item.description: The Ugly Duck When we talk about the word monolithic, many engineers have negative feelings about it. Some might say, “Expanding a monolithic application is very hard,” or “Maintaining a monolithic app is an exhausting task.” Often, we assume these claims are true simply because they relate to monolithic design. We frequently hear negative comments about monolithic architecture and praise another architecture, microservices, as if it’s the ultimate solution. But what if I told you there are multiple ways to build a monolithic application, and if done correctly, it is much easier for a small team to maintain and expand these apps?

item.title: Daily Drive with Linux
item.description: From the Beginning Getting software to work on Windows is an easy task: just click an installer, click the next button, let the installation bar run to 100%, and boom, you’ve installed software on a Windows machine. But when it comes to ‘development tools’ such as Docker, compilers, Kubernetes, etc., you will find that installing these tools on Windows is quite complex and not so straightforward. That’s why I chose Linux as my daily driver OS on my personal and work laptop for almost 5 years now.

item.title: Who am I
item.description: About Myself Hi, internet wanderer. My name is Dheeto. I am an ex-pharmacist currently working as a software engineer in Bangkok, Thailand. You might wonder, “How come?” I ended up in software engineering. Well, let me explain it to you. First Few Years of My Career I graduated from pharmacy school in early 2020, the year that COVID-19 hit. The healthcare industry wasn’t affected that much, so I could still find a job pretty easily and worked as a laboratory technician for almost three years.
